climbs.name: The Further Adventures of Trogdor the Burninator
climbs.fa: Darin Berdinka, Drew Brayshaw, Jordan Peters June 2003

content.description:
To quote the original FA description, 

"We climbed 4 or 5 pitches of 5th class rock (1.5 solid and 2.5 choss) and innumerable pitches (2000') more or less of 3rd class, 4th class, and 5.dirt. Parts of this route had been previously climbed by goats to judge by the evidence. 

 

Our route could have been much more harder and much more chestbeatworthy but darin and jordan managed to routefind us away from all the steep, loose upper walls and onto a treed ridge when they were in the lead"

Expect large detached pillars and rock that changes lithology multiple times per pitch on the technical pitches. 80' runouts off #0 TCUS and stuff.



On the left hand side of the wall. See TOPO

A light rack with zerocams and RPs and a lot of other junk. No pins. Expect to empty out your shoes several times on the gravel pitches.

climbs.name: On Black Lassie's Trail
climbs.fa: Paul Kendrick, Greg Maurer, Rob Tomich May 2-3 1981

content.description:
Start to the right of the Weremouse. Climb the buttress on the right of the gully, that the alt. start to the Weremouse climbs the left side of. After 5 or 6 pitches, pass a gendarme and climb a gravel ramp. Follow a chimney, face climbing and broken cracks and corners for many more pitches to a tree ledge. From a high tree ledge, several more pitches of 4th class reach the top.

see CAJ 1982, p.63



Right of the Weremouse. See TOPO

Same descent as the Weremouse.

Whatever gear you can get in. Helmets and double ropes mandatory. If you can find a case of Molson's discarded in the ditch, that will help too.

The central line on the face. "Begin at a large white slab below a yellow overhang, turn to the right, and head straight up for several pitches to the first tree ledge. It is also possible to begin further right and gain the lefthand buttress of a broad gully which is followed to the same tree ledge. From here, continue upwards for many pitches to the summit. Scrubby climbing with many variations"

see CAJ 1973, p. 62



Furthest right hand route on the face, See TOPO.

To descend head towards Lillooet and then follow goat and bighorn trails downhill. There's only one break in the cliff band above Highway 99, trust that the goat trail will take you to it,. You come down about 1 km east of the aqueduct.

Place whatever you can and expect loose rock and huge runouts. Lots of rope cutting potential. Goats will trundle on you as well.
A huge loose wall of rock just outside of Lillooet
